results.title: Sexual harassment: the employee perspective
results.brief_description: The aim of this program is to provide employees with an awareness of the Sexual Harassment issue and the role organisations play in determining policy and action. The program gives insight into the issue by dramatising several realistic situations which constitute harassment and by stressing the need for co-operative effort to deal with it. The video is accompanied by a manual which may be borrowed as a separate loan item.

results.title: Sexual harassment in schools
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, Sabina Baltrukomis and Victoria. Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: This program looks at some examples of sexual harassment in a school setting. Focuses on the consequences of harassing behaviour and avenues available to people who wish to take action to prevent it continuing. Ways of dealing with such incidences are suggested and legal rights under the Equal Opportunity Act 1984 are explained.

results.title: Sexual harassment
results.brief_description: This 13 segment video and guidebook dealing with sexual harassment in the work environment has been designed by psychologists, Eve Ash and Peter Quarry. Set in front of a studio audience including expert Barbara Wertheim, Commissioner of Equal Opportunity, and others who work in the area, this program looks at sexual behaviour, legal implications, effects on victims and strategies for deterring unwelcome advances. Includes four dramatisations of a man and a woman in harassment situations with follow-up discussions. Presented by Peter Quarry.

results.title: Sexism in the primary school (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Examines the hidden assumptions of school curricula and the ways in which teachers perpetuate sexist roles in children. A survey of sexism in traditional children’s literature is contrasted with a dramatisation of ‘St George and the dragon’ and observations of children at play are interspersed with comments by teachers with suggestions for a non-sexist and counter sexist curriculum

results.title: Sexing the label: love and gender in a queer world
results.creator_credit: Anna Broinowski, Lisa Duff and Froxoff Films
results.brief_description: An experimental documentary that explores identity politics around sex and gender that were prevalent in the 1990s. Arguing that sexual labels have become a political tool which can both empower or dispossess people, the film questions the limits of the stereotyping and categorizing that works to maintain the divide between gay and straight, male and female. Using Sydney’s long institutionalised Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras as its departure point, it moves on to challenge accepted labels within homosexual culture. Interviews with people who blur and subvert rigid categories of gender and sexuality by their refusal to be labelled, are combined with a poetic exploration of the ways that sexual and gender identities are literally inscribed upon the body. A provocative journey into queer culture featuring Quentin Crisp.

results.title: Sex: the Annabel Chong story (E)
results.creator_credit: Gough Lewis, David Whitten, Hugh F. Curry, Coffee House Films, Greycat Releasing and Omni International
results.brief_description: Annabel Chong was a university student in Los Angeles when she decided to enter the porn industry to finance her studies. This video commences soon after Annabel Chong has become famous for creating a world record in having sex with 251 men in one day. Resisting both a conservative and feminist anti-pornographic morality, Chong asserts her right as a woman and a feminist to both engage in the porn industry and to be unapologetic for her sexual desires and experience. But this ethically ambivalent documentary, filmed in a cinema-verite style in Chong’s home, on set of porn production houses in Los Angeles, and most disturbingly, in Chong’s parent’s home in Singapore, shows that for all the passion and sincerity of her passion, the pornographers creating, shaping and exploiting Chong’s sexual persona are all men. The filmmakers play on our voyeurism, beginning by titillating us and end up asking for our compassion: which makes for an uneasy but rivetting viewing experience. Annabel Chong, it needs to be said, is determined to refuse being portrayed as a victim. But ultimately sadness is the dominant emotion the viewer is left with by the end of this documentary. For all the apparent conviction of her beliefs, Annabel Chong seems immersed in a world in which she is used and exploited by men.

results.title: Sex: a guide for the young (E)
results.creator_credit: Svend Johansen, Multimedia Group of Canada and Filmforsyningen
results.brief_description: This very frank and explicit animated video covers many aspects of sexuality in an entertaining and educational way. The program was made in Denmark where they don’t ‘beat around the bush’ on the topic of sex. The program uses a general question and answer approach; answering many questions which may often be asked by young people. It touches on anatomy, sexuality, hygiene, contraception, AIDS and STD’s, condoms, orgasms, homosexuality, relationships, masturbation, just to name a few. WARNING: THE MATERIAL IS VISUALLY EXPLICIT.

results.title: Sex, lies and videotape
results.creator_credit: Steven Soderbergh, John Hardy, Robert Newmyer and Outlaw Productions
results.brief_description: A selfish, successful lawyer (Peter Gallagher) - whose wife (Andie MacDowell) has been turned off sex is having an affair with his sister-in-law (Laura San Giacomo). He welcomes an old college friend (James Spader) for a visit, not realising the amazing effect that he will have on all of them. A finely honed tale of adultery, impotence and dangerous liaisons. Strong women, weak men; a quartet defined by their erotic impulses and inhibitions. This is Steven Soderbergh’s first feature, and it won him Best Film and James Spader Best Actor at the Cannes Film Festival in 1989.
